title: What we are in an X meta really means.
body:
We are in a tank meta - We play tanks and ADCs.

We are in an assassin meta - We play assassins and ADCs.

We are in a mage meta - We play mages and ADCs.

We are in an ADC meta - We play ADCs and ADCs.

We are in a bruiser meta - We play bruisers and ADCs.

We are in a Support meta - We are fucking lying to ourselves.

It's not a problem because the champions designed for the role "bot" are being picked for the role "bot" every game. The same way that the champions designed for the role "top" or "Jungle" or "mid" or "support" are picked for those respective roles every game.

There are some select champions that are viable in 2, 3, or even 4 roles. Those champions are special cases. The vast majority of ADCs are NOT viable junglers (and the ones that are don't play ADC very often at all), yet the vast number of top laners are. Yet no one complains that it's a "top" meta because we see top lane champions every game and some games even see them in the jungle. Seeing bot lane champions every game and sometimes seeing them in mid or top is NOT a problem. 

The problem isn't that it's an "ADC meta", no less than there's a "top meta". If you must say there's a "diversity" problem, then the problem is that there are only about 18 marksmen. To which the solution would be to make a lot more marksmen, ~40 like the number of champions designed for other roles. Good luck with that - people would have your head.

In summary, ADC is a role. Marksmen is the champion type. Marksmen do a better job at ADC than any other champion, yet there are so few marksmen in the game. The perceived problem is due to the lack of marksmen.

Taking towers and sustained damage, while major assets of a Marksman champion, are not actually the reason they are in every game.

Rather, the reason lies in the fact that Summoner's Rift has 5 players, but only four resource streams. Temporal and spatial constraints make an even distribution of these resources impossible, meaning that two players have to share a resource stream for a large part of a match.
Resources come in two varieties: gold and experience. Gold is the resource that is more controllable in its flow to champions, as last-hitting awards the killer with the whole gold. XP, on the other hand, is shared between all nearby players.
This set-up makes it so that ideally, one of the champions in the shared resource stream gets all possible gold, while sharing the XP. The best champions for such a set-up are ones that give up the least of their power by sharing XP.
In essence, these champions are ranged, auto-attack based champions. Melees in general are bad XP sharers, as they need the defensive stats they get from leveling - usually, three to four defensive stats are tripled to quadrupled between levels 1 and 18. Meanwhile, ability-focused champions want the XP for base damage increases, utility increases and cooldown decreases - and sometimes, even the AD/AP conversion ratios benefit from ranking up an ability!
Ranged AA-based champions can afford to not level as quickly, as their main safety tool, their range, does usually not scale with champion level. For most of them, at least one of their abilities is a one-point wonder that is effective enough at rank 1, instead of a main damage tool - an example is Lucian, for whom ranking W and E does not majorly increase the damage. Also, for almost all Marksman, a BF Sword is about the same amount of AD they'd get from leveling up 17 levels.

This lowered impact of sharing XP is why there is always a Marksman botlane in League. No other class is less impacted by sharing XP in their overall efficiency.
The other sustained damage dealers, Juggernauts and Skirmishers, as well as some mages, are all more reliant on XP - Skirmishers are melee and often possess three damage dealing/rank scaling abilities (i.e. Riven with damage Q, damage W and defense E). Juggernauts are melee, possess some of the highest base stat scalings in the game (meaning they NEED these levels) and often feature three rank scaling abilities. Sustained damage mages are still ability-focused.
